commit_comments.body: Per the commit message, we are deliberately causing E_WARNING to be triggered when $args is omitted. They are passing insufficient arguments to the point where they risk security issues doing so.

We thought about it. We probably could have had it generate a notice in 3.5 and a warning in 3.6, but I was incredibly torn by the idea of shipping a notice that most developers wouldn't even see (let alone give themselves a chance to ignore it) when this is, at its heart, a potential security issue. Issuing a warning seemed like the most responsible thing to do, despite the (relatively minor) pain it'll cause.

I did a write-up here: http://make.wordpress.org/core/2012/12/12/php-warning-missing-argument-2-for-wpdb-prepare/.

A side-note, we've gotten very good (I say this facetiously) about accidentally breaking plugins that were doing something wrong in a major release, only to fix the issue in the next minor release after all of the plugins have updated for it. Happened with JavaScript enqueueing hooks in both 3.2 and 3.4. This was indeed a deliberate change, but there's nothing preventing us from moving to a notice in 3.5.1, then back to a warning in 3.6 again (hopefully giving developers some cover to make changes).

The methodology of this change is described in [this post](https://www.isecpartners.com/blog/2011/february/double-hmac-verification.aspx). It's a cheaper fix and isn't prone to implementing an algorithm that looks time-constant but isn't. We may reevaluate this in the future especially as PHP [will be introducing](https://wiki.php.net/rfc/timing_attack) a constant-time comparison function in a future version.

This is really suspect and confusing.
-  `$hmac` appears to not be defined anywhere in this scope. I assume it is a global set somewhere? Do you handle `$hmac` not being defined? Is that what you are 'hardening' against?
- Why are you hashing again when one of the inputs is a MD5 hash? At the very least, `$hash` is the result of `hash_hmac('md5', ...)` on the username and expiration, so it is unnecessary to hash it again unless your goal is to somehow 'harden' this test by applying a second level of hashing. It is unclear whether this accomplishes anything since you are doing the second layer for both values at the point of comparison (I can't imagine this does anything). Is the use of `hash_hmac` on both sides here an attempt to prevent side-channel timing attacks? If so, it is faulty, since you're still doing a string comparison on the end result. If you want to prevent side-channel timing attacks, use a constant-time string comparison, and don't use `hash_hmac` a second time. 
- Also, one could argue that comparing hashes of the values instead of comparing the values is introducing the possibility of a md5 collision attack here, but since `$hash` is already an md5 going in to the hash call, I'll assume `$hmac` is too so the risk is nil.

The property of a HMAC is that `HMAC(K, x) = HMAC(K, y)` if `x = y`. You've replaced the latter with the former.

(The only thing that should have been done, afaics, is replacing `!=` with `!==`, and then replacing `!==` with some constant-time comparison.)

Just FYI: this will still give issues if `$args` is a scalar or an object which doesn't implement `Countable`.

The function has been in WP since `4.2.0`. That hasn't changed.
What you want to do instead is add a second `@since` entry to annotate what has changed, like so:

```php
* @since 4.2.0
* @since 4.9.2 Added the `$directory_unblock` parameter.
```

For more information, have a look at the [WP PHP Documentation standards](https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/best-practices/inline-documentation-standards/php/).
Minor alignment issue - all parameter comments should be aligned.
I'm not sure the `$directories_unblock` name param name is descriptive enough. Also it reads weird, so might be better to rename to `$unblock_directories` or something.

You need to initialize the array with a `$path_blocked = array()` before this line or create the array like so:
```php
$path_blocked = array(
    'ROOT'           => rtrim( ABSPATH, '/' ),
    'WP_CONTENT_DIR' => WP_CONTENT_DIR,
    ...
);
```
Otherwise, PHP will throw error notices.

This is unclear.
Reading the code, these are expected to be the strings `'ROOT'`, `'WP_CONTENT_DIR'` etc, not the constants.
The documentation gives the impression that the constants are expected.

You'd probably be better off using `untrailingslashit()`.

Ref: https://developer.wordpress.org/reference/functions/untrailingslashit/

Before doing this, you will need to normalize the slashes - forward `/` vs backward `\`, i.e. Unix vs Windows - will give problems in this comparison.

You also need to pass the third parameter, `$strict`, to `in_array()` as otherwise, this comparison is vulnerable to hacks.

Ref: http://php.net/manual/en/function.in-array.php

Do you mean: "Whether the file has been deleted" ?

If so, the function would need to return the result of the `unlink()` call and it would need an additional `return false;` at the very end.

Otherwise the return value is inconsistent.
Same remarks here about the `@since` tag, the param comment alignment and clarification needed as above.
The filter will be able to bypass the block.
@lenonleite By not returning `true` when the delete has been executed, you make the return value inconsistent and unreliable, so please reconsider.

commit_comments.body: Per the commit message, we are deliberately causing E_WARNING to be triggered when $args is omitted. They are passing insufficient arguments to the point where they risk security issues doing so.

We thought about it. We probably could have had it generate a notice in 3.5 and a warning in 3.6, but I was incredibly torn by the idea of shipping a notice that most developers wouldn't even see (let alone give themselves a chance to ignore it) when this is, at its heart, a potential security issue. Issuing a warning seemed like the most responsible thing to do, despite the (relatively minor) pain it'll cause.

I did a write-up here: http://make.wordpress.org/core/2012/12/12/php-warning-missing-argument-2-for-wpdb-prepare/.

A side-note, we've gotten very good (I say this facetiously) about accidentally breaking plugins that were doing something wrong in a major release, only to fix the issue in the next minor release after all of the plugins have updated for it. Happened with JavaScript enqueueing hooks in both 3.2 and 3.4. This was indeed a deliberate change, but there's nothing preventing us from moving to a notice in 3.5.1, then back to a warning in 3.6 again (hopefully giving developers some cover to make changes).

The methodology of this change is described in [this post](https://www.isecpartners.com/blog/2011/february/double-hmac-verification.aspx). It's a cheaper fix and isn't prone to implementing an algorithm that looks time-constant but isn't. We may reevaluate this in the future especially as PHP [will be introducing](https://wiki.php.net/rfc/timing_attack) a constant-time comparison function in a future version.

This is really suspect and confusing.
-  `$hmac` appears to not be defined anywhere in this scope. I assume it is a global set somewhere? Do you handle `$hmac` not being defined? Is that what you are 'hardening' against?
- Why are you hashing again when one of the inputs is a MD5 hash? At the very least, `$hash` is the result of `hash_hmac('md5', ...)` on the username and expiration, so it is unnecessary to hash it again unless your goal is to somehow 'harden' this test by applying a second level of hashing. It is unclear whether this accomplishes anything since you are doing the second layer for both values at the point of comparison (I can't imagine this does anything). Is the use of `hash_hmac` on both sides here an attempt to prevent side-channel timing attacks? If so, it is faulty, since you're still doing a string comparison on the end result. If you want to prevent side-channel timing attacks, use a constant-time string comparison, and don't use `hash_hmac` a second time. 
- Also, one could argue that comparing hashes of the values instead of comparing the values is introducing the possibility of a md5 collision attack here, but since `$hash` is already an md5 going in to the hash call, I'll assume `$hmac` is too so the risk is nil.

The property of a HMAC is that `HMAC(K, x) = HMAC(K, y)` if `x = y`. You've replaced the latter with the former.

(The only thing that should have been done, afaics, is replacing `!=` with `!==`, and then replacing `!==` with some constant-time comparison.)

Just FYI: this will still give issues if `$args` is a scalar or an object which doesn't implement `Countable`.

The function has been in WP since `4.2.0`. That hasn't changed.
What you want to do instead is add a second `@since` entry to annotate what has changed, like so:

```php
* @since 4.2.0
* @since 4.9.2 Added the `$directory_unblock` parameter.
```

For more information, have a look at the [WP PHP Documentation standards](https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/best-practices/inline-documentation-standards/php/).
Minor alignment issue - all parameter comments should be aligned.
I'm not sure the `$directories_unblock` name param name is descriptive enough. Also it reads weird, so might be better to rename to `$unblock_directories` or something.

You need to initialize the array with a `$path_blocked = array()` before this line or create the array like so:
```php
$path_blocked = array(
    'ROOT'           => rtrim( ABSPATH, '/' ),
    'WP_CONTENT_DIR' => WP_CONTENT_DIR,
    ...
);
```
Otherwise, PHP will throw error notices.

This is unclear.
Reading the code, these are expected to be the strings `'ROOT'`, `'WP_CONTENT_DIR'` etc, not the constants.
The documentation gives the impression that the constants are expected.

You'd probably be better off using `untrailingslashit()`.

Ref: https://developer.wordpress.org/reference/functions/untrailingslashit/

Before doing this, you will need to normalize the slashes - forward `/` vs backward `\`, i.e. Unix vs Windows - will give problems in this comparison.

You also need to pass the third parameter, `$strict`, to `in_array()` as otherwise, this comparison is vulnerable to hacks.

Ref: http://php.net/manual/en/function.in-array.php

Do you mean: "Whether the file has been deleted" ?

If so, the function would need to return the result of the `unlink()` call and it would need an additional `return false;` at the very end.

Otherwise the return value is inconsistent.
Same remarks here about the `@since` tag, the param comment alignment and clarification needed as above.
The filter will be able to bypass the block.
@lenonleite By not returning `true` when the delete has been executed, you make the return value inconsistent and unreliable, so please reconsider.

commit_comments.body: Per the commit message, we are deliberately causing E_WARNING to be triggered when $args is omitted. They are passing insufficient arguments to the point where they risk security issues doing so.

We thought about it. We probably could have had it generate a notice in 3.5 and a warning in 3.6, but I was incredibly torn by the idea of shipping a notice that most developers wouldn't even see (let alone give themselves a chance to ignore it) when this is, at its heart, a potential security issue. Issuing a warning seemed like the most responsible thing to do, despite the (relatively minor) pain it'll cause.

I did a write-up here: http://make.wordpress.org/core/2012/12/12/php-warning-missing-argument-2-for-wpdb-prepare/.

A side-note, we've gotten very good (I say this facetiously) about accidentally breaking plugins that were doing something wrong in a major release, only to fix the issue in the next minor release after all of the plugins have updated for it. Happened with JavaScript enqueueing hooks in both 3.2 and 3.4. This was indeed a deliberate change, but there's nothing preventing us from moving to a notice in 3.5.1, then back to a warning in 3.6 again (hopefully giving developers some cover to make changes).

The methodology of this change is described in [this post](https://www.isecpartners.com/blog/2011/february/double-hmac-verification.aspx). It's a cheaper fix and isn't prone to implementing an algorithm that looks time-constant but isn't. We may reevaluate this in the future especially as PHP [will be introducing](https://wiki.php.net/rfc/timing_attack) a constant-time comparison function in a future version.

This is really suspect and confusing.
-  `$hmac` appears to not be defined anywhere in this scope. I assume it is a global set somewhere? Do you handle `$hmac` not being defined? Is that what you are 'hardening' against?
- Why are you hashing again when one of the inputs is a MD5 hash? At the very least, `$hash` is the result of `hash_hmac('md5', ...)` on the username and expiration, so it is unnecessary to hash it again unless your goal is to somehow 'harden' this test by applying a second level of hashing. It is unclear whether this accomplishes anything since you are doing the second layer for both values at the point of comparison (I can't imagine this does anything). Is the use of `hash_hmac` on both sides here an attempt to prevent side-channel timing attacks? If so, it is faulty, since you're still doing a string comparison on the end result. If you want to prevent side-channel timing attacks, use a constant-time string comparison, and don't use `hash_hmac` a second time. 
- Also, one could argue that comparing hashes of the values instead of comparing the values is introducing the possibility of a md5 collision attack here, but since `$hash` is already an md5 going in to the hash call, I'll assume `$hmac` is too so the risk is nil.

The property of a HMAC is that `HMAC(K, x) = HMAC(K, y)` if `x = y`. You've replaced the latter with the former.

(The only thing that should have been done, afaics, is replacing `!=` with `!==`, and then replacing `!==` with some constant-time comparison.)

Just FYI: this will still give issues if `$args` is a scalar or an object which doesn't implement `Countable`.

The function has been in WP since `4.2.0`. That hasn't changed.
What you want to do instead is add a second `@since` entry to annotate what has changed, like so:

```php
* @since 4.2.0
* @since 4.9.2 Added the `$directory_unblock` parameter.
```

For more information, have a look at the [WP PHP Documentation standards](https://make.wordpress.org/core/handbook/best-practices/inline-documentation-standards/php/).

You need to initialize the array with a `$path_blocked = array()` before this line or create the array like so:
```php
$path_blocked = array(
    'ROOT'           => rtrim( ABSPATH, '/' ),
    'WP_CONTENT_DIR' => WP_CONTENT_DIR,
    ...
);
```
Otherwise, PHP will throw error notices.

This is unclear.
Reading the code, these are expected to be the strings `'ROOT'`, `'WP_CONTENT_DIR'` etc, not the constants.
The documentation gives the impression that the constants are expected.

You'd probably be better off using `untrailingslashit()`.

Ref: https://developer.wordpress.org/reference/functions/untrailingslashit/

Before doing this, you will need to normalize the slashes - forward `/` vs backward `\`, i.e. Unix vs Windows - will give problems in this comparison.

You also need to pass the third parameter, `$strict`, to `in_array()` as otherwise, this comparison is vulnerable to hacks.

Ref: http://php.net/manual/en/function.in-array.php
